review.title: Multiobjective Optimization of Solar Powered Irrigation System with Fuzzy Type-2 Noise Modelling
review.abstract: Optimization is becoming a crucial element in industrial applications involving sustainable alternative energy systems. During the design of such systems, the engineer/decision maker would often encounter noise factors (e.g. solar insolation and ambient temperature fluctuations) when their system interacts with the environment. In this chapter, the sizing and design optimization of the solar powered irrigation system was considered. This problem is multivariate, noisy, nonlinear and multiobjective. This design problem was tackled by first using the Fuzzy Type II approach to model the noise factors. Consequently, the Bacterial Foraging Algorithm (BFA) (in the context of a weighted sum framework) was employed to solve this multiobjective fuzzy design problem. This method was then used to construct the approximate Pareto frontier as well as to identify the best solution option in a fuzzy setting. Comprehensive analyses and discussions were performed on the generated numerical results with respect to the implemented solution methods.

metadata.title: Multiobjective Optimization of Solar Powered Irrigation System with Fuzzy Type-2 Noise Modelling

sections.text: This chapter considered the dimensioning and design optimization of the solar-powered irrigation system, which is multivariate, noisy, nonlinear and multi-objective. Initially, this design problem was solved using the fuzzy type II approach to model the noise factors. Consequently, the Bacterial Foraging Algorithm (BFA) (within a weighted sum framework) was used to solve this multi-objective fuzzy design problem, which was then used to construct the approximate Pareto limit and identify the best solution option in a fuzzy environment. Comprehensive analysis and discussions were conducted on the generated numerical results with respect to the implemented solution methods. Keywords: solar-powered irrigation systems, metaheuristics, multi-objective optimization, type 2 fuzzy logic, warm intelligence, bacteria forming algorithms.

sections.heading: INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Diesel generators, gas turbines and other fossil-fuel-based energy systems have been widely used to control conventional irrigation systems. Currently, various issues related to the use of fossil fuels in energy systems (e.g. price fluctuations, environmental concerns and efficiency) have arisen. Therefore, the use of solar energy for irrigation of irrigation pumps has become very popular in recent studies (Helikson et al., 1991; Wong & Sumathy, 2001; Jasim et al., 2014; Dhimmar et al., 2014). The design and dimensioning of solar power systems has a strong impact on the reliability, emissions and efficiency of the system (AlAli et al., 2001). Challenges in the effective sizing of this system fall into the area of optimization, where the optimal sizing and design is achieved in order to achieve the following objectives (Shivrath et al., 2012; Carroqino al, 2009).

sections.heading: SIGMA DIVERSITY METRIC
sections.text: The diversity measure used in this work is the sigma diversity metric (Mostaghim and Teich, 2003).The sigma diversity metric (SDM) evaluates the positions of the solution vectors in objective space relative to the sigma vectors. For low-dimensional objective spaces (n 3), metrics based on spherical and polar coordinates could be used. However, since the dimensions go beyond three (n 3) indicators, the aforementioned coordinate systems do not well define the distribution of the solution vectors (Mostaghim and Teich, 2005).In such scenarios, the SDM is highly effective for the calculation of the solution distribution. To begin with the calculation of the SDM, two types of sigma lines would have to be constructed: the first sigma lines representing the solution vectors, and the sigma lines representing the reference lines representing the indicators-univertical indicators are the reference lines (sigma lines representing the solvectors-1, the solvectors-22, the solvectors-22, the indicators-where the indicators can be solved).

sections.heading: COMPUTATIONAL OUTCOME & ANALYSIS
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this project is a project, which is primarily a project, which is primarily a project, which is primarily a project.

sections.heading: CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The MO design of the solar-powered irrigation system was completed using type 2 fuzzy models to represent unsafe environmental factors; the dominance of the three generated Pareto limits was evaluated and classified; the design problem was successfully reformulated using type 2 fuzzy logic to represent uncertainty in the environmental data (as shown in Table 1); new optimal individual solutions were achieved as shown in Tables 3-5; and information on the effects of uncertainty on the variations in the targets was determined and analyzed, which would prove very useful for designers working with solar-powered irrigation systems operating in unsafe (or noisy) environments; and, using diversity metrics and the aggregate target function, the quality of the solutions and the behavior of the algorithm were analyzed when these irrigation systems are operated in an unsafe (or noisy) environment.

sections.heading: FUTURE RESEARCH DIRECTIONS
sections.text: In order to solve the problem of algorithmic uncertainty, the BFA should be implemented on this design problem in the future, but by varying its initialization parameters, thus identifying the optimal parameters for solving this design problem with uncertain environmental factors. In addition, other conventional fuzzy-based approaches (Vasant et al., 2010; Ganesan et al., 2014) could be upgraded to a type 2 fuzzy framework and applied to this problem. Other forms of metaheuristic approaches, such as the use of evolutionary strategies, could be implemented for this design problem (Ganesan et al., 2015). Other metrics, such as the hypervolume indicator, could be used to measure the degree of dominance of the generated pareto-frontiers (Zitzler and Thiele, 1998). A study to rigorously determine the fuzzy parameters (Equation (3)) could be conducted to try to achieve a better modelling accuracy of this design, which would be very useful for future researchers.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
sections.text: The authors are very grateful to the reviewers for their efforts to provide useful and constructive insights that the author overlooked in the preparation of the manuscript. The authors would also like to thank the Universiti Teknologi Petronas for their support in carrying out this work. Special thanks go to our friends, colleagues and students who continue to inspire and support us at all stages of our research.

Some of the most popular SI-based techniques are, cuckoo search (CS) (Yildiz, 2013), ant colony

To effectively handle such problems, higher order fuzzy logic (FL) such type-2 FL approaches are often employed in tandem with optimization techniques (Castillo and Melin, 2012; Ontoseno et al., 2013; Sánchez et al., 2015). Most existing research works involving the application of type-2 FL systems revolve around control theory and control system design (Fayek et al., 2014; Martinez et al., 2011; Bahraminejad et al., 2014; Oh et al., 2011; Linda and Manic, 2011). For instance in Wu and Tan (2004), the authors investigated the effectiveness of evolutionary type-2 FL controllers for uncertainty modelling in liquid-level processes.

multiobjective optimization) (Chen et al., 1995). Real-world optimization problems often contain large degrees of uncertainties. To effectively handle such problems, higher order fuzzy logic (FL) such type-2 FL approaches are often employed in tandem with optimization techniques (Castillo and Melin, 2012; Ontoseno et al., 2013; Sánchez et al., 2015). Most existing research works involving the application of type-2 FL systems revolve around control theory and control system design (Fayek et al., 2014; Martinez et al., 2011; Bahraminejad et al., 2014; Oh et al., 2011; Linda and Manic, 2011). For instance in Wu and Tan (2004), the authors investigated the effectiveness of evolutionary type-2 FL controllers for uncertainty modelling in liquid-level processes. In that work, the authors employed the genetic algorithm (GA) to evolve the type-2 FL controller. This approach was found to perform very well for modelling uncertainties in complex plants compared to conventional type-1 FL frameworks. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), a type-2 FL controller was employed for pitch control in wind turbines.

To effectively handle such problems, higher order fuzzy logic (FL) such type-2 FL approaches are often employed in tandem with optimization techniques (Castillo and Melin, 2012; Ontoseno et al., 2013; Sánchez et al., 2015). Most existing research works involving the application of type-2 FL systems revolve around control theory and control system design (Fayek et al., 2014; Martinez et al., 2011; Bahraminejad et al., 2014; Oh et al., 2011; Linda and Manic, 2011). For instance in Wu and Tan (2004), the authors investigated the effectiveness of evolutionary type-2 FL controllers for uncertainty modelling in liquid-level processes. In that work, the authors employed the genetic algorithm (GA) to evolve the type-2 FL controller. This approach was found to perform very well for modelling uncertainties in complex plants compared to conventional type-1 FL frameworks. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), a type-2 FL controller was employed for pitch control in wind turbines. Pitch control in wind turbines are critical for power regulation and reduction of fatigue load in the components of the turbine. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), the type-2 FL controller was shown to significantly improve the adjustment of the pitch angle, rotor speed and power output of the wind turbine generator.

Most existing research works involving the application of type-2 FL systems revolve around control theory and control system design (Fayek et al., 2014; Martinez et al., 2011; Bahraminejad et al., 2014; Oh et al., 2011; Linda and Manic, 2011). For instance in Wu and Tan (2004), the authors investigated the effectiveness of evolutionary type-2 FL controllers for uncertainty modelling in liquid-level processes. In that work, the authors employed the genetic algorithm (GA) to evolve the type-2 FL controller. This approach was found to perform very well for modelling uncertainties in complex plants compared to conventional type-1 FL frameworks. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), a type-2 FL controller was employed for pitch control in wind turbines. Pitch control in wind turbines are critical for power regulation and reduction of fatigue load in the components of the turbine. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), the type-2 FL controller was shown to significantly improve the adjustment of the pitch angle, rotor speed and power output of the wind turbine generator. Similarly, in Allawi (2014), a type-2 FL controller was utilized for controlling robots involved in cooperation and target achieving tasks in multi-robot navigation systems.

In that work, the authors employed the genetic algorithm (GA) to evolve the type-2 FL controller. This approach was found to perform very well for modelling uncertainties in complex plants compared to conventional type-1 FL frameworks. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), a type-2 FL controller was employed for pitch control in wind turbines. Pitch control in wind turbines are critical for power regulation and reduction of fatigue load in the components of the turbine. In Bahraminejad et al., (2014), the type-2 FL controller was shown to significantly improve the adjustment of the pitch angle, rotor speed and power output of the wind turbine generator. Similarly, in Allawi (2014), a type-2 FL controller was utilized for controlling robots involved in cooperation and target achieving tasks in multi-robot navigation systems. In that work, the controllers were optimized using the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and the Hybrid Reciprocal Velocity Obstacles techniques. The author discovered that the optimized type-2 FL controller performed very well for controlling such robots. Besides control theory and engineering, type-2 FL has also been employed for modelling systems endowed with high levels of uncertainty. For instance in Paricheh and Zare (2013), a type-2 FL system was used to predict long-term traffic flow volume.

multiobjective optimization) (Chen et al., 1995). Real-world optimization problems often contain large degrees of uncertainties. To effectively handle such problems, higher order fuzzy logic (FL) such type-2 FL approaches are often employed in tandem with optimization techniques (Castillo and Melin, 2012; Ontoseno et al., 2013; Sánchez et al., 2015). Most existing research works involving the application of type-2 FL systems revolve around control theory and control system design (Fayek et al., 2014; Martinez et al., 2011; Bahraminejad et al., 2014; Oh et al., 2011; Linda and Manic, 2011). For instance in Wu and Tan (2004), the authors investigated the effectiveness of evolutionary type-2 FL controllers for uncertainty modelling in liquid-level processes. The works of Castillo and Melin (2012) and Dereli et al., (2011) provides a more comprehensive review on type-2 FL systems applied in industrial settings.
optimization (ACO) (El-Wahed, 2008), PSO (Kennedy and Eberhart, 1995) and bacterial foraging algorithm (BFA) (Passino, 2002).
optimization (ACO) (El-Wahed, 2008), PSO (Kennedy and Eberhart, 1995) and bacterial foraging algorithm (BFA) (Passino, 2002).

optimization (ACO) (El-Wahed, 2008), PSO (Kennedy and Eberhart, 1995) and bacterial foraging algorithm (BFA) (Passino, 2002). In many past research works, PSO has been implemented extensively for solving nonlinear optimization problems. Recently, alternative optimization strategies such as BFA has become attractive to be implemented for such purposes. BFA‘s computational performance has been demonstrated to be as good as and sometimes better than other SI-based techniques (Al-Hadi and Hashim, 2011). BFA is inspired by the natural behavior of the E. Coli bacterium. This behaviour involves the search mechanisms utilized by the bacteria during nutrient foraging. These mechanism were then employed by Passino (2002) to design the BFA for solving complex optimization problems.
In Mezura-Montes et al., (2014), the design optimization of a crank-rocker-slider (variable transmission) system was performed using BFA.
BFA has also been applied in cellular manufacturing systems (Nouri and Hong, 2013).
In economic load dispatch, the target is to obtain the most optimal load dispatch for the power generating units while taking into account variable load demands and load constraints (Vijay, 2012).
economic and efficient) in flexible alternating current transmission system (FACTS) devices (Ravi et al., 2014).
The design optimization problem in Mezura-Montes et al., (2014) was formulated in two forms (singleobjective and bi-objective).

The design optimization problem in Mezura-Montes et al., (2014) was formulated in two forms (singleobjective and bi-objective). The authors then restructured the conventional BFA for multiobjective optimization. The conventional and multiobjective techniques were successfully implemented to optimize the mechanical design of the crank-rocker-slider system. BFA has also been applied in cellular manufacturing systems (Nouri and Hong, 2013). In these systems, the cell formation issue is tackled while considering the number of exceptional elements and cell load variations. In Nouri and Hong (2013), using the BFA approach, part families and machine cells were generated by the authors.

The design optimization problem in Mezura-Montes et al., (2014) was formulated in two forms (singleobjective and bi-objective). The authors then restructured the conventional BFA for multiobjective optimization. The conventional and multiobjective techniques were successfully implemented to optimize the mechanical design of the crank-rocker-slider system. BFA has also been applied in cellular manufacturing systems (Nouri and Hong, 2013). In these systems, the cell formation issue is tackled while considering the number of exceptional elements and cell load variations. In Nouri and Hong (2013), using the BFA approach, part families and machine cells were generated by the authors. In Panda et al., (2009), the BFA was seen to aid the manufacturing process of rapid prototyping.
OVERVIEW OF TYPE-2 FUZZY LOGIC Type-2 fuzzy sets are generalizations of the conventional or type-1 fuzzy sets (Zadeh, 1975).

metadata.abstractText: Optimization is becoming a crucial element in industrial applications involving sustainable alternative energy systems. During the design of such systems, the engineer/decision maker would often encounter noise factors (e.g. solar insolation and ambient temperature fluctuations) when their system interacts with the environment. In this chapter, the sizing and design optimization of the solar powered irrigation system was considered. This problem is multivariate, noisy, nonlinear and multiobjective. This design problem was tackled by first using the Fuzzy Type II approach to model the noise factors. Consequently, the Bacterial Foraging Algorithm (BFA) (in the context of a weighted sum framework) was employed to solve this multiobjective fuzzy design problem. This method was then used to construct the approximate Pareto frontier as well as to identify the best solution option in a fuzzy setting. Comprehensive analyses and discussions were performed on the generated numerical results with respect to the implemented solution methods.
metadata.creator: Microsoft® Word 2010
